block.p: International A3-11 SERBS SEEK LEADER'S OUSTER Thousands of protesters in Belgrade called for the resignation of their President as Serbia began to feel the effects of United Nations sanctions. But President Milosevic insisted that Serbia was not responsible for the fighting that led to world condemnation of his Government. A1 VOW OF VENGEANCE IN SARAVEVO In their vows to keep fighting, avenge lost comrades and capture Sarajevo, Serbian fighters offer little hope that they will yield any time soon to international pressure. A1 Bush Administration officials express reluctance to use force. A8

International A3-11 SERBS SEEK LEADER'S OUSTER Thousands of protesters in Belgrade called for the resignation of their President as Serbia began to feel the effects of United Nations sanctions. But President Milosevic insisted that Serbia was not responsible for the fighting that led to world condemnation of his Government. A1 VOW OF VENGEANCE IN SARAVEVO In their vows to keep fighting, avenge lost comrades and capture Sarajevo, Serbian fighters offer little hope that they will yield any time soon to international pressure. A1 Bush Administration officials express reluctance to use force. A8

SOUTH AFRICA ON THE BRINK Angered by what it views as foot-dragging by the white minority Government, the African National Congress resolved to paralyze South Africa with strikes, boycotts and demonstrations to force swifter progress toward majority rule. A3 ITALY BEGINS TO FEEL STIGMA After decades in which politics were laughed off as a sideshow to its all-important economy, Italy is beginning to fear that its system may not measure up to an integrated Europe's standards. A8 TIGHTENING ISLAM'S GRIP ON SUDAN The Government is moving to transform the Sudan, where one-third of the people are not Muslims, into an Arabic-speaking state dedicated to spreading Islamic militancy. A6 EUROPEANS PUSHING ENERGY TAX A proposal to fight pollution and global warming by imposing an energy tax on oil and other harmful, non-renewable sources may help the European Community seize the moral high ground at a summit meeting this week in Rio de Janeiro. A6 For Rio de Janeiro, the Earth Summit is a big morale booster. A6 JAPAN DILUTES PLAN FOR FORCE In a possible setback to a plan to send soldiers abroad for United Nations peacekeeping operations, the Government yielded to a compromise that would create a symbolic force but prevent it from leaving Japanese shores for years. A1 China is accused of torturing 3 men who defaced a picture of Mao. A9 Thousands angered by a land dispute rioted in an Iranian city. A10 Ethnic fighting and political change throw Rwanda into chaos. A11 Israelis celebrate 25 years of full control over Jerusalem. A3 National A12-15, B7 A NEW BREED OF LAWMAKERS The growth of suburbs in the 1980's is now dramatically changing the face of state legislatures and Congressional delegations, as redistricting favors the election of minorities and Republicans. A1 TRUTH AND ADVERTISING In one of the first systematic looks at how prescription drugs are advertised, researchers at U.C.L.A. reported that advertisements in medical journals were often misleading about the safety and effectiveness of new drugs. A1 HOW NORMAL CAN YOU GET? Tulsa, Okla., is the most typical town in America, according to an analysis of 1990 census data. That may not appear to be much of a distinction, but Corporate America thinks otherwise. A1 THE LATEST BRIGHT IDEA In what appears to be a significant advance in the technology of efficient lighting, a new light bulb will be introduced today that uses a high-frequency radio signal instead of a filament to produce light. It easily could last 14 years. A1 AID AFTER THE RIOTS Federal aid is already reaching those who lost jobs, homes and businesses in the Los Angeles rioting, but some community leaders say the Government must try harder to make more residents aware of the aid programs. A12 A PLACE OF ONE'S OWN For Sale: Town in Colorado Rockies, no neighbors, no residents, the perfect getaway for nature lover with $250,000 to spare. A12 JUDGES UNDER FIRE The election challenge to a judge who sentenced a Korea-born grocer to probation for killing a black girl in Los Angeles raises the question of whether judges and juries are becoming vulnerable to public second-guessing and retribution for making unpopular decisions. A13 RETHINKING A WAR ON POVERTY There was a consensus on what we know but not on what to do, when some of the nation's most eminent poverty researchers met over the weekend to survey decades of disappointments and a future of seemingly pinched prospects. A13 A MODEL CAMPAIGN Representative Barbara Boxer's campaign for a California Senate seat blends several salient characteristics of this election season, not always to her advantage. A14 RACE FOR THE FUTURE The two closely matched Republican candidates for a California Senate seat agree on little except that their race is a barometer for the future of the party in the nation's most populous state. A14 Bill Clinton on democracy now and outhouses then. A14 Collect names for Perot in New Jersey. A15 MAKING DO WITHOUT THE COMICS Two weeks into a strike that has shut down their operations, Pittsburgh's two daily newspapers are experimenting with alternative ways to get the news and other information to their readers. B7 Metropolitan Digest, B1 MOVING BACK TO THE STREET Every month about 75 families, because of personal problems or problems with city-owned apartments, move out of subsidized housing and back onto the streets, which is to say, back into the city's bureaucratic shelter system. A1 Business Digest D1 Sports C1-9 Baseball: Brewers edge Yanks. C1 Mets get a rain break. C5 Basketball: Stage set for Drexler's rise. C1 U.S. women's team goes for experience. C6 Golf: Douglass wins. C9 Hockey: Strategy fails against Penguins. C7 Soccer: U.S. defeats Ireland. C9 Tennis: A Courier rout. C3 Obituaries B10 James Gibson, judge Arts/Entertainment C10-16 Tony Award winners. C11 A novelist on drug culture. C11 Earth Summit and the arts. C16 Music: "Elektra" at Spoleto. C10 Daugherty and Field. C10 Dance: City Ballet's Diamond Project. C11 Editorials/Op-Ed A16-17 Editorials A16 Fiscal insanity.

Letters A16 Leslie H. Gelb: A Balkan plan. A17 William Safire: Perot 'hardship' mystery deepens. A17 Sheldon Krimsky: Tomatoes may be dangerous to your health. A17 Russell Jacoby: Those campus C.E.O.'s. A17
